main_text:
Why Do Comparative Philosophy If It’s So Hard?
4. Why Do Comparative Philosophy If It’s So Hard?

The most obvious sin of doing comparative philosophy is assimilating
another tradition to one’s own by unreflectively importing
assumptions, frameworks, and agendas into one’s reading of that
other tradition. Sometimes too much charity (as a principle of
interpretation) is insufficiently respectful of the distinctness of
the other tradition. There are more subtle dangers. If one is a
dissident from main trends in one’s home tradition, one is
tempted to find another tradition that “got it right.”
This is fine as long as the desire to find another such tradition does
not lead to distortion or oversimplification of that other tradition
(see Hansen, 1992, 2004, for discussions of taking Confucianism as
representative of the Chinese tradition as a whole and of trying to
find in Confucianism something one may perceive as lacking in
one’s own tradition). The result is a kind of
“Orientalism” (Said 1978) that is turned on its head, so
that the radical other is now superior. 

Another debate involving this sort of possibility was initiated by
Goldin (2003) and later on taken up by Slingerland (2013), who have
criticized interpretations (e.g., in Ames, 1993; Jullien, 2007) that
take Chinese thought to be innocent of commitment to mind/body dualism
(which is implicitly or explicitly deemed to be a fundamental error).
They present historical and textual evidence to argue that some sort
of mind/body dualism operated within many if not all early Chinese
texts. Slingerland also backs up his conclusions with qualitative and
quantitative analysis designed to guard against cherry-picking
passages from texts guided by one’s preconceptions of what is in
them. He uses keyword-focused random sampling of passages from the
pre-Qin corpus of received texts supplemented by recently discovered
archaeological texts from Guodian. Goldin emphasizes that different
texts will reveal different views about the relationship of mind and
body, whereas Slingerland is inclined to think the texts tend to
reveal belief in a “weak dualism” he believes to be a
human universal. Weak dualism falls in between a strong dualism that
posits an ontological distinction between mind and body, such as
Descartes’ claim that mind and body are distinct substances with
nothing in common, on the one hand, and a strong “holism”
that asserts no qualitative differences between mind and body. Weak
dualism holds that there are functional and qualitative differences
between mind and body without asserting ontological distinction.
Slingerland sometimes mentions “weak holism” as a possible
fourth position, but its difference with weak dualism is unclear.

Raphals (2015) does explicitly include the latter as a fourth position
and seems to distinguish the two intermediate positions according to
whether they emphasize more or less the distinction between mind and
body, noting that there is no firm boundary between the two.
Mencius’ conception of mind and body seems to fall somewhere in
this intermediate zone. He regards mind (xin) as an organ of
the body whose function is to think, and it has the four sprouts of
goodness. Thus there are functional and qualitative distinctions he
makes between mind and the (rest of the?) body, and the mind is
certainly functionally distinct, but it is consistent with what he
says to regard mind as composed of the same energy-stuff (qi)
that composes the body. Indeed, Chinese metaphysics later came to
commonly recognize qi as the universal stuff of the world. On
the other hand, as Goldin points out, no less a text than the
Zhuangzi provides passages that suggest the possibility of
disembodied minds, such as speculation that a dying friend might next
turn up as a rat’s liver or an insect’s leg. Raphals
points out much of the interest and the variety of ways in which early
Chinese thought relates the mind to the body as lying not in the
dualist/holist contrast but in the details, such as the body portrayed
as the container of the mind, or the mind being ruler of the body.
Comparing ideas from Greek and Chinese texts, she finds that neither
dualism nor holism is anyone’s cultural property.

The dangers of reading into another tradition one’s own peculiar
assumptions on the one hand and on the other hand excessively
“othering” it (even if in the service of saying they were
right) are hard to avoid, or at least hard to avoid being accused of
falling prey to them. It is hard enough to master a single tradition
to the point where one can avoid saying silly things about it. Are the
risks worth it?

One reason for thinking so is that comparative philosophy is an
instance of a sound and sensible strategy for doing philosophy. When
facing hard problems it is simply a good strategy to consider a wide
range of enduring, respected ideas bearing on those problems. We of
course must be wary of the possibility that the other tradition is not
really addressing the same problem we are, or that it is addressing
only part of the problem we are addressing. But when there is common
address of a problem, it is not always the case that one tradition
must be adjudicated as entirely right and the other as entirely wrong.
There is a good possibility that each tradition has something
insightful to say about some aspect of the problem and that each
tradition could incorporate something of what the other tradition has
to say (see Yu and Bunnin, 2001). Yu (2007) appropriates
Aristotle’s conception of the friend as a second self, a mirror,
by which one can come to know oneself better, one’s unexamined
presuppositions, for instance. May Sim (2007) argues that
Aristotle’s metaphysics of the soul supplies a substantial self
that is both needed and presupposed by Confucius’ virtue ethics.
At the same time she argues that Aristotle’s metaphysics tilts
too far towards an individualism that does not motivate sufficient
attention to the culturally laden social relations required by his own
ethics of character and politics of virtue, and so Aristotelian ethics
could benefit by taking from Confucianism an acknowledgment of the
ethical importance of ceremony and decorum. When one crosses
traditions in enacting such strategies, there is the opportunity for
fruitful interaction and mutual influence. Already discussed above is
the opportunity for fruitful interaction between rights-oriented
traditions and traditions such as Confucianism focused on the value of
relationship and community.

Consider another area of potential interaction: when a tradition as
long-lived and as sophisticated as the Confucian tradition brims full
with writing on the nature of agency, human motivation, and the
problem of developing ethical excellence and commitment, one cannot
afford to ignore it (see Ivanhoe, 2000, for portraits of the tradition
of Confucian and neo-Confucian thinkers on these subjects).
Confucianism and Daoism emphasize the need to to pay attention to the
concrete details of the situation at hand and displays healthy
skepticism about the power of general principle to reveal what sort of
action is suitable to the situation. Confucianism displays an
appreciation for the power of community, custom, convention and
ceremony for helping to make vivid and concrete and meaningful such
ethical abstractions as love, respect, and care (Fingarette, 1972,
Shun, 1993, Kupperman, 2004). From these themes, there is much to be
learned, especially if one’s home tradition has had a strong
focus for a good portion of the modern period on the top-down
deduction of specific ethical judgments from extremely abstract
principles. At the same time, an appreciation for the concrete and for
the culturally specific may obscure the possibility of general and
transcultural principles that help to evaluate the concrete and
culturally specific, and the Chinese tradition could benefit from
interaction with the Western (Cua, 1985). In fact, one’s case
for the existence of transcultural principles becomes stronger when
one dives into other tradition and finds correlates to important
themes in one’s own tradition. 

Flanagan (2017) identifies Mencius’ theory of the moral sprouts
as the ancient precursor of moral modularity theory, an example of
which is Haidt’s moral foundations theory. Just as Mencius held
that there are in contemporary parlance automatic,
affective-cognitive-conative (prompting to action) inclinations and
intuitions (such as our alarmed and distressed reaction upon seeing a
child about to fall into a well) that could develop into the moral
virtues (such as ren or humanity), so Haidt theorizes that
there are several such modules or “foundations”
(Haidt’s look somewhat different from Mencius’, but one
of Haidt’s modules is “harm/care or
suffering/compassion”) that form moralities. Flanagan compares
Mencius’ and Haidt’s theories, and finds that each
possesses a different set of strengths and weaknesses. For example,
Mencius’ theory correctly does not encourage us to think that
the sprouts, which begin as automatic, intuitive reactions, remain
that way. One of the other Mencian sprouts is the capacity to make
distinctions between shi and fei (that’s it,
and that’s not it, where the first has the connotation of
approval and the second the connotation of disapproval), and this
develops into the virtue of zhi or wisdom. It looks as if
this sprout is the inborn capacity that forms the basis of analogical
reasoning and other kinds of reflection that in fact go into the
development of the other sprouts. For example, natural compassion can
grow into the virtue of humanity only when we learn how to care for
others and respond to their suffering in an appropriate fashion.
Flanagan thinks this is the right kind of picture. If we are talking
about moral development, what begins as automatic and intuitive should
develop into something that is guided by knowledge, reflection and
reasoning. By contrast, Haidt’s theory holds that the modules go
all the way up, in the sense that they remain largely automatic and
intuitive. On the other hand, Haidt’s theory shows a well-taken
sensitivity to the possibility that the modules could take different
forms in different cultures and societies, that some modules could
receive greater emphasis in some moralities, and that in fact
different moralities result from such variation in emphasis. 

Finally, recall the case of the Buddhist ideal of impersonal concern
being brought to bear on a debate in Western philosophy over the
viability of ideals of impersonal concern. This illustrates the point
that comparative philosophy can stretch one’s sense of
possibility, in this case, of human possibility. That is a benefit in
itself.

Comparative philosophy that is done along the Chinese-Western axis can
proceed from one end or the other, in the attempt to bring to bear
concepts, frameworks, and insights from one tradition to the project
of making progress on questions and problems in the other tradition.
Kwong-loi Shun (2009) has observed that there has been an asymmetry in
the amount of work done in these two possible directions. There is
much more work done that starts from the Western end and works towards
the Chinese end. Shun questions whether there is a good intellectual
grounding for this asymmetry, given that Chinese philosophy promises
to illuminate some aspects of the ethical life that are not as well
appreciated or studied in Western philosophy. The alternative, as Shun
puts it, is that “that there is no such grounding and that the
[asymmetrical] tendency is just a collective phenomenon explainable in
terms of historical trends that wax and wane over time” (2009,
p. 475). In speculating about possible explanations exemplifying
Shun’s second alternative, it is worth reminding ourselves that
the trends of philosophy are often reflections or distillations of
larger historical trends and the shifting balances of power between
different regions of the world. If this is so, we may be witnessing an
incipient correction in the asymmetry between Chinese and Western
philosophy.

Whether such a sociological trend is fruitful is a question for
philosophical exploration. Sometimes what is gained through
comparative inquiry starts with the realization that concepts or major
distinctions that one has taken for granted as central to
philosophical inquiry are not taken to be so central or even have no
close equivalents in another philosophical tradition. That may further
raise the issues of what role that concept is playing in the first
tradition, whether the second tradition has no need for that role, and
whether this implies some fundamental difference in their orientations
toward the ethical life. Shun’s work (2014, 2015) on approaches
to anger and resentment, and on the absence of a concept of
forgiveness in Confucianism is an interesting case in point. The way
that this work points to a fundamental difference in orientation
toward the ethical life might best be brought out in comparison with
P.F. Strawson’s characterization of resentment as “a
reaction to injury or indifference.” It is an instance of the
class of “reactive attitudes” that rest on, and reflect,
an expectation of, and demand for, “the manifestation of a
certain degree of goodwill or regard on the part of other human beings
towards ourselves;” or at least“an absence of the
manifestation of indifferent disregard” (2008, 15). Resentment,
then, is based on a sense of what is due to oneself, and may be
conceived as a defense of self-respect. Forgiveness may be conceived
as the foregoing of resentment, and a prominent form of forgiveness
that became established in the West is based on the idea that it
should only be given if the offender repents. Shun points out that
Confucians generally regard resentment (yuan) as an emotion
one should rise above. Though anger might be appropriate as a response
to someone else’s wrongful treatment of the self, it is properly
directed at the wrongful treatment rather than at the fact that it was
directed at oneself rather than someone else. One should be focused on
determining the appropriate response going forward. This downgrading
of the ethical status of resentment helps to explain the absence of an
equivalent in Classical Chinese for forgiveness, especially the kind
that should be given only if the offender repents. Resentment is not
regarded as something one may rightfully bear unless the offender
repents. Shun stresses that the generally negative attitude toward
resentment in Confucianism does not imply a lack of concern for
self-respect. The basis for self-respect should be the morality of
one’s own actions and character, not how others treat one.

There are conceptions of forgiveness in the Western tradition that are
closer in ethical spirit to the Confucian idea that one should rise
above resentment, such as ones that forgive the offender in order to
avoid bitterness and self-consuming anger and seek meaning and purpose
in striving to prevent further wrongdoing in the future. However, it
is significant that a very prominent form of Western forgiveness is
the foregoing of resentment, which in turn is regarded as appropriate
and at one’s discretion to forego. It may be revealing of the
underlying ethical orientation that the focus is on what others owe to
the self, and that the basis of self-respect should depend on how
others treat one. That it is focused on the self may be an indication
of Western individualism, but it is also arguably social in a way that
makes self-respect dependent on how others treat one. In this regard,
Confucianism expresses a more independent spirit in locating the basis
of self-respect in how the self responds to wrongdoing and not
primarily to what was done to oneself. Comparative philosophy can
result in surprising comparisons that require qualification of the
usual broad-stroke comparisons such as individualistic versus social
orientations.
section_title: 4. Why Do Comparative Philosophy If It’s So Hard?
